title: 1. What Is Pitch?
lede: Pitch is simply how high or low a sound feels.
introParagraphs: If you hear a tiny bird chirping, that's a high pitch.
If you hear a big drum, that's a low pitch.
Every sound you hear has a pitch — some are musical, some are just noise.
In music, we name pitches using notes, and learning to recognize them is the first step to strengthening your musical ear.

sections.content: Think of pitch like the 'height' of a sound:
In KYPitch, you'll learn to hear these differences clearly and confidently.

title: 2. The Musical Alphabet (A–G)
lede: Music uses a simple alphabet made of seven letters.
introParagraphs: The musical alphabet contains only the letters A B C D E F G.
After G, the pattern repeats again — but the notes may sound higher or lower.
These repeating notes form the foundation of all music you hear.

sections.content: Even though the note letters repeat, their pitch level changes depending on the octave.

items: The letter stays the same, but the pitch can change

sections.content: KYPitch begins with the note A because it is the universal reference note used in tuning.

title: 3. What Are Octaves?
lede: Octaves are higher or lower versions of the same note.
introParagraphs: If you hear two notes both named A, but one sounds deeper or brighter, they are in different octaves.
Octaves describe the 'height' of the same note.

sections.content: Examples of the note A in different octaves:
Think of octaves as floors of a building — same layout, different height.

title: 4. Why A4 Is the Starting Point (440 Hz)
lede: A4 is the universal tuning note used by musicians around the world.
introParagraphs: A4 vibrates at 440 times per second — this is known as 440 Hz.
This pitch is in the middle of the human hearing comfort zone.
Using A4 makes it easier to compare higher and lower notes.

items: It’s neither too high nor too low
It helps the ear learn pitch relationships

sections.content: Most KYPitch exercises begin with A4 so learners can build a stable reference.

title: 5. What Is Frequency?
lede: Pitch comes from how fast a sound vibrates.
introParagraphs: Every sound is created by vibrations.
Frequency tells us how fast something vibrates per second.
Higher vibration speed means a higher pitch. Lower vibration speed means a lower pitch.

sections.content: You can imagine frequency like shaking a rope:

items: Shake fast = tight waves = high pitch
Shake slow = wide waves = low pitch

sections.content: All notes in KYPitch are based on these vibration speeds.

title: 6. Octave Ranges You Will Learn
lede: Each octave has a unique feel and sound.
introParagraphs: KYPitch gradually introduces octaves so you don't get overwhelmed.
Training across multiple ranges helps your ear identify pitch accurately.

title: 7. How Instruments Produce High and Low Notes
lede: Instruments create pitch based on size and vibration.
introParagraphs: Bigger objects vibrate slower, producing lower sounds.
Smaller or tighter objects vibrate faster, producing higher sounds.

sections.content: Understanding this helps your ear anticipate pitch naturally.

title: 8. Ear Training Basics
lede: Ear training is a learnable skill — anyone can do it.
introParagraphs: You don’t need musical background to recognize pitch.
Your brain learns pitch through repeated exposure and comparison.

items: Listen — become familiar with the sound

sections.content: Regular practice strengthens your auditory memory just like learning a new language.

title: 9. How KYPitch Tests Work
lede: KYPitch helps you identify notes through repetition and feedback.
introParagraphs: Each test plays a note from one of the available octaves.
You choose which octave you believe the note belongs to.
The app gives immediate feedback so you learn instantly.

items: Notes play randomly within your level
Incorrect answers help your brain compare differences

title: 10. Practice Tips for Better Pitch Recognition
lede: Small habits make ear training easier and faster.
introParagraphs: You will learn faster by practicing consistently, not intensely.
Even 5 minutes a day can upgrade your pitch sense dramatically.

items: Don’t rush — early mistakes are normal
